docs.title: Drum Sound – Massive Attack (SD3)
docs.text: Drum Sound at Massive Attack (SD3)

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Drums dark, heavy, atmospheric, with soft kick and dry snare, typical of 90s Bristol trip-hop (Mezzanine, 100th Window).

docs.title: 1. Choosing a kit in SD3.
docs.text:
• Start with a Ludwig 70s kit or Gretsch (they are already dark and full).
  • Use few cymbals → dark HH, no bright crashes (or keep them but filtered).
  • Watch out for Overheads and Room: they are critical, more than close-mics.

docs.title: 2. Routing in SD3
docs.text:
• Kick → Direct Out (clean).
  • Snare → Direct Out.
  • HH and cymbals → turn it down a lot, keep it almost like "background noise".
  • Room → keep it high, it will be the glue of the kit.
  • Overheads → turn them down and filter out the highs, so they stay dark.

docs.title: 3. Processing in Logic
docs.text: Kick - EQ: cut 250 Hz (-3 dB), boost to 60-70 Hz (+3 dB) → sub soft. - Slow compressor (30-40 ms attack) → let breathe. Snare - EQ: low cut 150 Hz, boost 200 Hz (+2 dB body), slight +3 dB at 2-3 kHz (snap). - Light saturation (Overdrive or Tape Delay trick). Hi-Hat / Cymbals - EQ: low pass 8-10 kHz → no brightness. - Short delay (1/16, low feedback) for movement. Room - Aggressive compressor (FET 1176 style, 8:1 ratio, fast attack, medium release) → characteristic "pump". - EQ: High cut 6 kHz for darkening.

docs.title: 4. Bus Drums Processing
docs.text:
• Parallel compression ("Super Punchy") → adds body and aggression.
  • Room + Overhead dark → mix it with the main bus.
  • Some dark ambient reverb (2-3 s, filtered).

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Deep, dark kick.
  • Dry snare, with character but not bright.
  • Compressed room that becomes part of the groove.
  • Cymbals almost hidden, only as texture.
  • Dark, hypnotic atmosphere → Massive Attack mood.

docs.title: Drums Section
docs.text:
• #1 - Parallel Punchy Chain with Saturn / Pro-Q4 / 1176 (ratio 4:1, att 3, rel 7), low cut 120 Hz → punch and saturation.

  • #2 - Ambient/Dark Parallel Multiband comp → dark EQ (cut 10-12 kHz, boost 400-500 Hz) → tape sat → reverb dark 2-3s.

  • #3 - Punch Electronic/Modern Parallel Transient Designer (Attack +, Sustain -) → 1176 All Buttons In → EQ 60-80 Hz + 3-4 kHz → Saturn Warm Tube type saturation.

  • #4 - Drums Bus Ambient/Dark Dark EQ (high cut, 200 Hz boost) → Light VCA/Opto Compressor (2-3 dB GR) → Dark Short Room (Space Designer, mix ~10%) → Light chorus optional.

  • #5 - Drums Bus Punchy EQ for presence → Comp VCA 2:1, medium attack, fast release → light saturation → limiter punch.

docs.title: Layering Kick+Snare – Massive Attack (Hybrid)
docs.text: Layering Kick & Snare style Massive Attack (acoustic-electronic hybrid)

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: To combine the organic depth of SD3's acoustic kit with the controlled beat of electronic samples → the typical Massive Attack mix (real drums + programmed elements).

docs.title: 1. Kick - Acoustic + electronic layer
docs.text:
• Acoustic (SD3): take Ludwig/Gretsch dark kick → EQ as in #10 (cut 250 Hz, boost 60-70 Hz).
  • Electronic: add a sample sub-kick or "808 tail" (also inside SD3 Electronic EZX if you have it, otherwise any sample).
  • Routing: put sub-kick in parallel, filter it:
    • Low Pass at 100 Hz (sub only).
    • Mix low (10-20%), just enough to fill the bass. **Result: electronic beat under the acoustic body.

docs.title: 2. Snare - Dry layer + texture
docs.text:
• Acoustic (SD3): dry, filtered and darkened snare (low cut 150 Hz, boost 200 Hz).
  • Electronic: add a clap, or a dark electronic snare sample.
  • Routing:
    • Electronic clap/snare → High-pass EQ (above 800 Hz), no low body.
    • Mix at 20-30%. **Result: acoustic body + electronic clap = snare more present without getting bright.

docs.title: 3. Room & Overhead
docs.text:
• Keep acoustic Room high, compressed (aggressive pump).
  • Electronic layers go DRY (no reverb) → so they stay dry and contrast with Room.

docs.title: 4. Bus Drums
docs.text:
• Glue compressor (VCA 2:1, 2-3 dB GR).
  • Parallel punch bus to bring out kick/snare.
  • Light saturation (Overdrive) to blend acoustic + electronic.

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Deep kick with electronic sub underneath.
  • Organic snare with electronic "tail".
  • Dark, compressed room that breathes.
  • Result → acoustic/electronic hybrid in Massive Attack style, ready for downtempo/ambient trip-hop.

docs.title: FX / Ambient section
docs.text:
• #6 - Reverbs Ambient Bus Space Designer Plate short (1.2s) → ChromaVerb Hall long (3-4s, modulated, filtered).

  • #7 - Textures Bus (Shimmer) EQ band-pass (300-5k) → Overdrive (Drive 3-4 dB, Tone ~4-5 kHz) → Pitch Shifter +12 semitones → ChromaVerb Hall 4-6s → shimmer.(Variant: Pitch -12 semitones → dark shimmer)

docs.title: 1. Channel EQ (gentle tilt)
docs.text:
• Low Shelf: -1 dB below 40 Hz → cleans up excessive subs.

  • High Shelf: -1.5 dB above 10 kHz → slightly darkens the mix (Massive Attack feel).

  • If more presence is needed → +1 dB at 2-3 kHz.

docs.title: 2. Multipressor (gentle glue)
docs.text:
• Low band (20-120 Hz): Ratio 1.5:1, GR max 1-2 dB.

  • Mid band (120-4k): Ratio 1.5-2:1, GR 1-2 dB.

  • High band (4k-20k): Ratio 1.5:1, GR 0.5-1 dB. ** All very light → serves only to control without crushing.

docs.title: 3. Tape delay (stereo widener trick)
docs.text:
• Delay: 1/64 L - 1/64 R

  • Feedback: 0%

  • Mix: 5-8%. ** Used not as a delay but as a "character": adds stereo micro-phases that widen the mix without chorus.

docs.title: 4. Exciter (dark and thin)
docs.text:
• Amount: 5-7%

  • Frequency: 3-5 kHz ** Just a trickle of air/harmonica, just to keep the treble from collapsing too much.

docs.title: 5. Adaptive Limiter (final glue)
docs.text:
• Output Ceiling: -0.3 dB

  • Gain: adjust to have LUFS around -12/-11 (don't push too hard, let's leave dynamic). ** It is more "mixbus limiter" than final mastering.

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Dark but deep → bass drum and snare remain in the foreground, cymbals and treble controlled.

  • Stereo wide but not fake.

  • Dynamics preserved (not crushed by heavy limiter).

docs.title: 1. Channel EQ (character)
docs.text:
• Low Shelf: +1.5 dB at 60 Hz → gives weight to kick.

  • Light Cut -2 dB at 250 Hz → takes away mud.

  • Boost +1 dB at 3 kHz → brings out snare and vocals. ** EQ more pronounced than in ambient version.

docs.title: 2. Compressor (Studio VCA or Vintage VCA)
docs.text:
• Ratio: 2:1

  • Attack: 20-30 ms (lets transients pass)

  • Release: 80-120 ms (breathe on the slow trip-hop groove)

  • Threshold: adjust to have 2-3 dB of constant GR. ** Glue + light pumping, very Massive Attack style.

docs.title: 3. Saturator (Overdrive or Tape Delay trick)
docs.text:
• Use Overdrive with Drive 2-3 dB, Tone 6-7 kHz. ** Adds analog grit, makes kit "dirtier".

(or "Tape Delay" with Feedback 0%, Dry/Wet 5-10% per tape color)

docs.title: 4. Exciter
docs.text:
• Amount: 10-15%.

  • Frequency: 4-6 kHz ** More treble boost → makes hi-hats and rooms breathe without making them bright.

docs.title: 5. Adaptive Limiter
docs.text:
• Output Ceiling: -0.3 dB

  • Gain: raise up to -9 / -8 LUFS if you want a modern boost (but watch out for dynamics). ** Brings your mix to "club-ready" level while maintaining punch.

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Kick and snare in the face, deep bass.

  • Dark saturation, not bright, reminiscent of Bristolian sound.

  • Harsher limiter than the ambient version, but still musical.

Trick: You can keep two versions of the master bus** (Ambient and Punchy) and duplicate the Output track in Logic. Bypass one or the other depending on the track, without having to redo the settings.

docs.title: EQ (Channel EQ)
docs.text:
• Sub cleanup: -1 dB @ 40 Hz (Low Shelf)

  • Anti-mud: -2 dB @ 250 Hz (Medium Q, wide)

  • Presence (if needed): +1 dB @ 2-3 kHz

  • Dark tilt: -1/-1.5 dB above 10 kHz (High Shelf)

docs.title: Compressor (Studio VCA / Vintage VCA)
docs.text:
• Ratio: 2:1

  • Attack: 20-30 ms (lets transient pass)

  • Release: 80-120 ms (breathe with the slow groove)

  • Threshold: adjust for 2-3 dB of Gain Reduction on the meter

  • Make Up Gain: just enough to compensate

** Soft glue, not squashed.

docs.title: Saturation (Overdrive or Tape Delay trick).
docs.text:
• Overdrive: Drive 2-3 dB, Tone 5-6 kHz

  • Or: Tape Delay → Feedback 0%, Mix 5-10%. ** Adds analog grain without overdrive.

docs.title: Exciter
docs.text:
• Amount: 5-10%

  • Range: 3-6 kHz ** A strand of harmonic air, useful to keep treble from collapsing after cuts.

docs.title: Limiter (Adaptive Limiter)
docs.text:
• Ceiling: -0.3 dB

  • Gain:

    • Ambient → up to -12 / -11 LUFS (dynamic)

    • Punchy → up to -9 / -8 LUFS (more aggressive)

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Dark and warm, without sharp highs.

  • Glue due to light compression.

  • Punch if you turn up the limiter more.

  • Grank with metered saturation/exciter.

You can keep two versions saved as Output Channel Strip Settings**:

  • Ambient Master (more dynamic, less driven)

  • Punchy Master (more compression and limiter, grittier).

docs.title: Bus Reverbs Ambient - double reverberation (Eno style).
1. Space Designer → Short plate (for presence and body).
docs.text:
• IR Sample: Plate Small (choose one "bright" or "dark" to taste)

  • Length: 1.2-1.3s (maximum)

  • Pre-Delay: 20-30 ms → separates direct sound well from reverb

  • Internal EQ:

    • High Cut: 5 kHz

    • Low Cut: 200 Hz

  • Stretch: 100% (if you want more density you can try 80-90%)

  • Dry/Wet Mix: 100% (you are on Aux)

  • Output Level: 0 dB (manage from the Aux fader in Logic).

**Result: a dark, short plate that gives presence without overwhelming.

docs.title: 2. ChromaVerb → Long hall (for depth and atmosphere).
docs.text:
• Algorithm: Hall

  • Decay: 3-4s

  • Pre-Delay: 40-50 ms (so the tail comes in later and stays "spacey")

  • Density: 80-90% (denser = more "sound cloud")

  • Modulation: Depth 15-20% → "breathing" motion

  • EQ (integrated in ChromaVerb):

    • Low Cut: 200 Hz

    • High Cut: 6-7 kHz

  • Mix: 100% (Aux)

  • Output Level: 0 dB

**Result: a huge, dark, modulated space that creates the typical "Eno" atmosphere.

docs.title: Reverberations / Space (Eno style)
docs.text:
• Typical chain:

    • Long reverb → Plate or Hall (2-4 sec), filtered with low cut 200 Hz and high cut 5-6 kHz.

    • A short delay (80-120 ms) before the reverb → adds "pre-space" and keeps the sound from going to the tail immediately.

    • Slow modulation (very light chorus/phaser or an LFO on the filter) to let the reverb breathe.

  • Eno trick: create multiple reverbs in parallel with different decays (e.g., one short and dark, one long and thin), and blend them. It becomes a soundscape instead of just an effect.

docs.title: 1. Channel EQ (general color).
docs.text:
• Kick area: a slight boost at 60-70 Hz (+2 dB, Q wide).

  • Snare body: small lift to 200 Hz (+1.5 dB).

  • Mud cut: cuts slightly at 250-300 Hz (-2 dB, medium Q) → reduces "boomy".

  • Presence: +1-2 dB at 3-4 kHz to give life to snare drum and cymbals. **Beware: don't overdo it, these are subtle tweaks.

docs.title: 2. Compressor (FET style → 1176 emulation).
docs.text:
• Circuit Type: Studio FET

  • Ratio: 4:1

  • Attack: 30 ms (medium, allows bass drum and snare transients to pass through).

  • Release: 100 ms (medium-fast, breathe in time).

  • Gain Reduction: 3-5 dB. ** Gives "glue" without crushing too much → very Massive Attack style: punch but dark.

docs.title: 3. Tape Delay (only for subtle movement).
docs.text:
• Sync: 1/8 L, 1/16 R

  • Feedback: 10-15%

  • Wet: 8-10% (very low, it almost has to "not feel") ** This creates you a short stereo delay that gives amplitude and groove to hi-hats and percussion.

docs.title: 4. Optional: Exciter or Saturation
docs.text: • You can insert the Exciter plugin (Logic → Distortion → Exciter) with Amount 5-10% only on the high end (5 kHz-10 kHz). **It gives you a thread of brightness if you hear the kit too dark.

docs.title: Routing with other buses.
docs.text:
• Drums Bus → Stereo Out (clean, with glue and EQ).

  • A send to your Parallel Bus (Super Punchy), as you already do, to add bang.

  • A light send to the Reverbs Ambient (especially HH and snare).

** Result:

  • The Drums Bus holds everything together.

  • The Parallel adds punch.

  • The Ambient Reverbs and Textures make the drums breathe in space.

docs.title: Drums Bus dark ambient
docs.text: Drums Bus "dark/ambient "

docs.title: Drums Bus (Ambient/Dark version).
docs.text:
1. Channel EQ

    • Low Shelf: -1/-2 dB below 60 Hz (remove unnecessary subs)

    • Wide Boost +2 dB at 150-200 Hz (warm body)

    • Cut wide -2/-3 dB at 5-6 kHz (darken)

  2. Compressor (Studio VCA or Vintage Opto)

    • Ratio: 2:1

    • Attack: 40-50 ms (slow)

    • Release: 150-200 ms (breathe in time)

    • Threshold: adjusted to have only 2-3 dB gain reduction (look at center meter) ** Battery stays alive, only slightly stuck.

  3. Space Designer (short dark room, direct insert)

    • IR: a small Room (0.5-0.8s)

    • Pre-delay: 15-20 ms

    • High Cut: 4-5 kHz

    • Low Cut: 200 Hz

    • Dry: 0 dB

    • Rev: -18 dB (equals low mix, ~10%) ** Dark halo holding the kit together.

  4. Optional - Very light chorus (for "sound fog")

    • Rate: 0.2 Hz

    • Depth: 10%

    • Mix: 5-8% ** Very subtle movement on the tails, almost imperceptible.

docs.title: Routing with other buses.
docs.text:
• Drums Bus goes straight to Stereo Out.

  • Light send to your Parallel Punchy (to add attack when needed).

  • Send to Reverbs Ambient (especially HH and snare) → so it gets into the soundscape.

** Result: Drums Bus becomes soft, dark, atmospheric → does not invade but "breathes" in space. Perfect for ambient/downtempo tracks.

docs.title: Practical use
docs.text:
• With this setup the battery becomes softer, velvety and immersed.

  • It doesn't foreground, but creates atmosphere → perfect for dark ambient/downtempo tracks.

  • Mix it with your Parallel Punchy if you want some attack coming out.

docs.title: How to save everything in Logic
Where Logic saves channel strip settings.
docs.text:
• Logic puts the .cst (channel strip setting) files in the user folder:

    ~/Music/Audio Music Apps/Channel Strip Settings/

    Inside you will find subfolders for Audio, Instrument, Bus, Output.

  • When you save from Logic → "Save Channel Strip Setting As...," the file ends up there.

docs.title: How to create your custom folder.
docs.text:
1. Go to the folder:

    ~/Music/Audio Music Apps/Channel Strip Settings/

  2. Inside "Bus" (since yours are Aux/Bus), create a new folder:

    S2D01 Ambient FX

  3. Save your settings directly there (when you do Save As, Logic allows you to navigate to that folder).

docs.title: How you call them up in Logic.
docs.text:
• When you open the Setting menu on the channel strip of an Aux, you will see your S2D01 Ambient FX folder appear.

  • Inside will be all your personal presets: Reverbs Ambient, Textures Shimmer, Super Punchy Drum Parallel, etc.

** So you no longer have to search randomly through the huge menus: you have a library "branded" for your project.

docs.title: 1. Save as Channel Strip Setting.
docs.text:
• Go to the Bus/Aux you want to save (e.g., Textures).

  • At the top of the channel strip, in the Setting menu, click Save Channel Strip Setting As....

  • Give it a name (e.g., Textures Shimmer). **This saves the entire effects chain and parameters. When you open another Aux in the future, you can load that chain right away.

docs.title: 2. Use a Project Template
docs.text:
If you want to always find all your Aux ready-made (Ambient Reverbs, Textures, Drum Parallel, etc.), then:

  1. Set up the project with all the buses as you like.

  2. Go to File → Save as Template....

  3. When you open Logic, you will immediately find it on the home screen among your custom templates.

💡 Summary:

  • Single aux → save as Channel Strip Setting.

  • Complete setup with multiple Aux → save as Project Template.

docs.title: Hi Hat & Percussioni Trip Hop
docs.text: Hi-Hat & Trip-Hop Percussion

docs.title: Target
docs.text: Hi-hat and percussion that doesn't shine too brightly, remains dark, hypnotic and rhythmic, becoming part of the mood rather than an in-your-face element.

docs.title: 1. Hi-Hat (acoustic or electronic)
docs.text:
• EQ:
    • High Cut: 8-10 kHz → no excessive brightness.
    • Slight boost to 2-3 kHz if presence is needed.
  • Processing:
    • Short Ping-Pong delay (1/16 or 1/8, feedback 10-15%, mix 15-20%) → hypnotic movement.
    • Optional: Light saturation (Overdrive Drive 2 dB, Tone 4-5 kHz).

docs.title: 2. Percussion (congas, bongos, various drums).
docs.text:
• EQ:
    • Low-pass at 6-7 kHz → always dark.
    • A small bump at 200-300 Hz for warmth.
  • Processing:
    • Slow tremolo (Rate 1/2 or 1/4, Depth 20-30%) → creates a "pulse" effect.
    • Short dark room (Space Designer 0.8-1s, filtered).

docs.title: 3. Creative Layering
docs.text:
• You can add filtered noises (vinyl crackle, field recording) in sync with hi-hats → they become part of the groove.
  • Optional: Reverse FX on single hits → atmospheric transitions.

docs.title: 4. Bus Percussion (optional)
docs.text:
• Collects hi-hats and percussion in a dedicated bus.
  • Processing bus:
    • Compressor Opto ratio 2:1, GR max 2 dB → glue.
    • Light saturation → amalgam.
  • Generous send to Reverbs Ambient → so they blend into the soundscape.

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Hi-hat and percussion become hypnotic, dark and soft, always part of the atmosphere → no pop brilliance.
  • Slow, sensual, "smoky" groove → typical Massive Attack trip-hop sound.

docs.title: Rhythms (Massive Attack style)
docs.text:

  • Light saturation (Overdrive or Tape Delay trick).

docs.title: Hi-Hat / Cymbals
docs.text:
• EQ: low pass 8-10 kHz → no brightness.

  • Short delay (1/16, low feedback) for movement.

docs.title: Room
docs.text:
• Aggressive compressor (FET 1176 style, 8:1 ratio, fast attack, medium release) → characteristic "pump".

  • EQ: High cut 6 kHz to darken.

docs.title: 4. Bus Drums Processing
docs.text:
• Parallel compression ("Super Punchy") → adds body and aggression.

  • Room + Dark Overheads → mix them with the main bus.

  • Some dark ambient reverb (2-3 s, filtered).

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Deep and dark kick.

  • Dry snare, with character but not bright.

  • Compressed room that becomes part of the groove.

  • Cymbals almost hidden, only as texture.

  • Dark, hypnotic atmosphere → Massive Attack mood.

docs.title: Where to look in SD3.
docs.text:
1. Library Core (Superior Drummer 3 Default Library)

    • The kits recorded by George Massenburg have beautiful, dark rooms.

    • Start with a kit like Ludwig or Gretsch and work your way up to processing.

  2. EZX/SDX expansions (if you have them or want to get them)

    • Hip-Hop EZX → already has kick and snare sampled in trip-hop style.

    • Dark Matter EZX → cinematic/industrial sounds that lend themselves to dark atmospheres.

    • Electronic EZX → acoustic-electronic hybrids, useful if you want layering.

  3. Practical Trick

    • Get a dark acoustic kit (e.g., Ludwig 70s) → process it with dark EQ + parallel comp + saturation.

    • Layera kick/snare with an electronic sample (even stock inside SD3) → typical Massive Attack approach.

docs.title: Basically.
docs.text:
• You will not find an "Unfinished Sympathy Kit" preset.

  • But with a dark kit (Ludwig, Gretsch), attenuated overheads, compressed room, and some saturation, you'll get pretty close.

  • If you want to get straight to the point, Hip-Hop or Dark Matter expansions save you time.

docs.title: Ambient/Dark Parallel
docs.text:
Objective: depth, movement, dark and enveloping atmosphere.

Recommended chain:

  1. Compressor OTT (or Logic Multipressor in 3-band mode)

    • compresses a lot on treble, medium-light on bass.

    • Is used to make cymbals velvety and let transients breathe.

  2. Dark EQ

    • cuts above 10-12 kHz, soft roll-off.

    • Small enhancement at 400-500 Hz (+2 dB) to give body.

  3. **Tape Saturation / Decapitator in "Tape" mode.

    • little drive, just to "fog".

  4. Reverb long and dark (2-3 sec, plate or hall filtered).

    • Mix 100% (if you use it only on parallel).

    • Low cut at 200 Hz, high cut at 5-6 kHz. ** Mix very softly in the mix: it's like a "sound veil" that gives depth.

docs.title: Bonus Ambient/Downtempo
docs.text:
• On the DRUMS PARALLEL you can also add a dark, long reverb → the result is a kit that stays natural on the main bus but has a full, atmospheric ambient tail on the parallel.

  • You can even distort it a bit (Saturation / Overdrive) to give it character.

** This is a trick all sound engineers use: from Andy Wallace in rock to people like Brian Eno in ambient (he more with parallel reverbs).

docs.title: Parallel Compression
docs.text: Parallel compression setup for battery.

docs.title: Step 1 - Create the drums bus.
docs.text:
1. In the Logic Mixer select all Auxes of Superior Drummer (Kick, Snare, HH, Toms, OH, Room).

  2. Set their output not to "Stereo Out," but to a Bus (e.g., Bus 10).

  3. Logic creates you a new Aux (Bus 10) → rename it "DRUMS BUS." ** Now all the kit goes through there.

docs.title: Step 2 - Duplicate it for parallel.
docs.text:
1. On the DRUMS BUS, create a Send (e.g., Bus 20).

  2. Logic opens you a new Aux (Bus 20) → rename it "DRUMS PARALLEL."

  3. Set the Send to Pre-fader and set it to 0 dB. **This way you have a kit clone that does not depend on the volume of the main bus.

docs.title: Step 3 - Compress like an animal.
docs.text:
On the DRUMS PARALLEL channel:

  • Put a nice aggressive compressor (Logic Compressor in VCA or FET mode).

  • Ratio: 8:1 or 10:1.

  • Short attack (5-10 ms).

  • Fast release (50-100 ms).

  • Threshold so that it "crushes" hard (also 10-15 dB gain reduction).

** Result: parallel bus sounds pumped, fat and present.

docs.title: Step 4 - Mix the two worlds.
docs.text:
• Slowly turn up the volume of DRUMS PARALLEL below the DRUMS BUS clean.

  • Find the point where the drum "breathes" but at the same time has the most bang.

docs.title: Punch Electronics/Modern
docs.text:
Goal: Club beat, aggressive thrust that makes subwoofers dance.

Recommended chain:

  1. Transient Designer

    • Attack +30%, Sustain -20%.

    • Kick and snare puncture immediately.

  2. 1176 "All-Buttons-In " style.

    • Ratio on 20:1, Attack medium, Release fast.

    • Compression that musically crushes and distorts.

  3. Surgical EQ

    • Boost +4/5 dB at 60-80 Hz (kick thump).

    • Boost +4 dB at 3-4 kHz (snap snare/platters).

  4. Analog/ Saturn distortion in Warm Tube mode.

    • Mid-high drive, 50% mix. **Higher mix than clean bus: this parallel becomes part of the sound, not just seasoning.

docs.title: Basically:
docs.text:
• Ambient/Dark → colors the space, adds atmosphere.

  • Electronic punch → adds violence and presence.

  • Super Punchy Drum Saturation (your own) → remains the perfect middle ground for rock/organic downtempo.

docs.title: Super Punchy Drum Saturation
docs.text:
That chain you made for yourself (Saturn + Pro-Q4 low cut + 1176) is exactly the classic parallel punch bus approach that serious sound engineers use:

  • Saturn → it adds harmonics and "grit" to you.

  • Pro-Q4 with the low cut below 120 Hz → brilliant, because then you don't mess with the speaker subs (you leave the bass clean on the main bus).

  • 1176 FET (ratio 4, attack 3, release 7) → fast, mean compression, perfect for blasting out snare drums and cymbals.

Output 15 / Input 33 = nice bang, you're really pushing the machine to get it saturated.

** Two veteran ideas you could add to your "Super Punchy Drum Saturation."

  1. EQ boost mid-highs after the compressor.

    • A 3-5 kHz bell (+2/3 dB) → brings out even more snare drum crack and cymbal attack.

  2. A pinch of short/dark reverb only on the parallel.

    • Short plate type (0.7-1s), low mix (10-15%).

    • Result: parallel not only pumps, but "widens" in space without kneading.

So you would have: Saturn → Pro-Q4 (low cut) → 1176 → (optional) EQ lift → plate reverb dark.

docs.title: Workflow Eno + Massive Attack - ONLY with Logic effects.
1. Bus "Ambient Reverbs "
docs.text:
Create a dedicated Aux (Bus 20 for example), call it Reverbs Ambient.

** Chain effects (Logic stock):

  1. Space Designer (first instance).

    • Type: Plate

    • Length: ~1.2s

    • Internal EQ: High Cut 5 kHz, Low Cut 200 Hz

    • 100% Mix (you are on an Aux)

  2. ChromaVerb (second instance, in series).

    • Type: Hall

    • Decay: 3-4s

    • Pre-delay: 30-40 ms

    • High Cut: 6 kHz

    • Low Cut: 200 Hz

    • Modulation: Depth 15-20% → to give "breathing space"

** Use:

  • Snare/HH → send a little (20-30%)

  • Kick → little to none

  • Texture → a lot (50-70%)

docs.title: 2. Bus "Textures "
docs.text:
Dedicated aux (Bus 30), call it Textures. Here you send noises, pads, reverse.

** Chain effects:

  1. Channel EQ

    • Activates only one Band-Pass:

      • HPF at 300 Hz

      • LPF at 5 kHz

    • Result: more "telephone-like" textures, without extremes.

  2. Overdrive (Logic → Distortion → Overdrive).

    • Drive: 3-4 dB

    • Tone: 4.0

    • Output: -2 dB (to compensate) ** Simulates Saturn "warm tape".

  3. ChromaVerb (Shimmer emulation)

    • Type: Concert Hall

    • Decay: 5-7s

    • Mix 100%

    • EQ: High Cut 7 kHz

    • Tip: Use the Pitch parameter → +12 semitones → shimmer effect.

** Use:

  • Send us pads, field recordings, slow synths.

  • The result is an atmospheric "veil" that lives behind the kit.

docs.title: 3. Drums Bus (Parent Stack)
docs.text:
This is the sum of your SD3 auxes.

** Typical effects:

  1. Channel EQ

    • Kick: boost 60-70 Hz, cut 250 Hz.

    • Snare: boost 200 Hz (body), one touch at 3 kHz (snap).

    • HH: LPF around 10 kHz (not too bright).

(you can also do this on individual auxes, but if you want a "color bus" do this)

  1. Compressor (Logic) → Circuit Type: FET

    • Ratio 4:1

    • Attack: 30 ms (medium-slow)

    • Release: 100 ms

    • Gain Reduction: 3-5 dB ** Gives cohesion, but lets the groove breathe.

  2. Stereo Delay (for percussion or HH)

    • Sync: 1/8 L, 1/16 R

    • Feedback: 15%.

    • Mix: 10% ** "Trip-hop" movement without covering.

docs.title: Final routing
docs.text:
• Drums Bus → Stereo Out

  • Reverbs Ambient → Stereo Out

  • Textures → Stereo Out **Three main faders to balance to taste.

docs.title: Workflow pratico in Logic Pro
docs.text: Practical workflow in Logic Pro

docs.title: STEP 1 - Organization with Dedicated Bus.
docs.text:
1. Create a "Drums Bus " → all Aux of SD3 in (already with Stack).

  2. Create a "Reverbs Ambient " → an Aux just for long/dark reverbs.

  3. Create a "Textures " → Bus where you send noises, pads, reverse, etc. **This way you immediately separate groove, space and ambience.

docs.title: STEP 2 - Bus "Ambient Reverbs"
docs.text:
• Insert 2 different reverbs in series/parallel:

    • Short dark slate (1.2s) → high cut at 5 kHz, low cut at 200 Hz.

    • Long hall (3-4s) → dark filtered, perhaps with a slow modulator (chorus/phaser).

  • You can dose them with different Send: Kick and Snare a little, Hi-Hat and texture a lot. ** You immediately have the "layered space" typical of Eno.

docs.title: STEP 3 - "Textures" bus.
docs.text:
• Here you send ambient recordings, synths, reverse FX.

  • Typical chain:

    • Band-pass EQ (300 Hz - 5 kHz).

    • Saturator (Saturn with a touch of "Warm Tape").

    • Shimmer reverb (pitch +12, 100% mix). ** This bus becomes the atmospheric spine behind the groove.

docs.title: STEP 4 - Drums Bus (Massive Attack feel).
docs.text:
• Kick: EQ to free 60-70 Hz, slow compressor.

  • Snare: parallel compression (use Super Punchy).

  • Percussion: low-pass filter (no excess brightness), short ping-pong delay. ** So you get heavy but dark grooves without getting "techno".

docs.title: STEP 5 - Routing and control.
docs.text:
• Send Drums Bus → a bit into the Ambient Reverbs (lots of hi-hat and snare, little kick).

  • Send Textures → a lot into the Ambient Reverbs (so they blend into the space).

  • Stereo Out → you already have the clean + dark + atmospheric sum.

-> You end up with three main faders controlling everything:

  • Drums Bus (energy)

  • Reverbs Ambient (space)

  • Textures (atmosphere)

docs.title: How to use them together
docs.text:
• Snare and HH → a little bit of Plate (for attack) + a touch of Hall (for tail)

  • Kick → very little Plate, almost no Hall

  • Texture and pad → mostly long Hall, little Plate

  • Environments and reverse FX → 100% Hall to create "soundscapes"

docs.title: Bus Textures in the style of :Shimmer"
Recommended chain (Bus Textures in shimmer style).
docs.text:
1. Channel EQ (band-pass 300 Hz - 5 kHz)

  2. Overdrive (Drive 3-4 dB, Tone ~4-5 kHz)

  3. Pitch Shifter

    • Semitones: +12 (for bright shimmer)

    • Mix: 100% wet

    • Fine Tune: 0

    • Latency Compensation: on "Low" (if it doesn't give you phase problems)

  4. ChromaVerb (Long Hall).

    • Decay: 4-6 s

    • Pre-delay: 40 ms

    • High Cut: 6-7 kHz

    • Low Cut: 200 Hz

    • Mod Depth: 15-20%

** Result: your textures enter the bus, are saturated/darkened, then raised an octave and finally sent into a long Hall → typical Eno style shimmer ✨

-> Variant: duplicate the Textures Bus, change the Pitch Shifter to -12 semitones and you have a dark shimmer. Mix the two buses and you get a huge and "celestial/demonic" carpet at the same time.

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: To create dark and deep sound carpets that fill the space between drums and harmonies, in full trip-hop/dark ambient style.

docs.title: 1. Source
docs.text:
• Field recordings: wind, distant traffic, rustling.
  • Noise generator (Logic: Test Oscillator → White/Pink noise).
  • Vocal/instrumental samples rendered unrecognizable (reverse, granular).

docs.title: 2. Basic processing
docs.text:
1. Channel EQ
    • Narrow band-pass: HPF 200-300 Hz / LPF 4-5 kHz.
    • Small boost at 500-800 Hz to give body.
  2. Bitcrusher (Logic)
    • Resolution: 12-14 bits (not too destructive).
    • Mix: 15-20% → adds dirt without ruining everything.
  3. Overdrive / Distortion
    • Drive: 2-3 dB
    • Tone: 2-3 kHz -> "lo-fi dark" color.

docs.title: 3. Spatiality
docs.text:
• Space Designer → Long dark hall (5-6s, filtered 200-5k).
  • Tremolo → Very slow rate (1/2 or 1/1), Depth 20-30%.
  • Optional: AutoPan at very slow rate → texture moves in stereo.

docs.title: 4. Shimmer dark (optional)
docs.text: • Pitch Shifter -12 semitones → ChromaVerb Hall 6-8s.-> A tail going down an octave, super "sonic abyss".

docs.title: 5. Bus Textures Extra-Dark.
docs.text:
• Put all textures in a dedicated bus.
  • Light glue (Opto comp, 2:1, 2 dB GR).
  • Final low-pass EQ 4-5 kHz → darken everything.

docs.title: Final character
docs.text:
• Noise and carpets that don't steal attention, but fill in the gaps.
  • Dirty, cinematic atmosphere, perfect for ambient/dark downtempo.
  • They can work even at very low volume: they feel rather than listen.

docs.title: Texture / Ambient layers
docs.text:
• Granular or shimmer reverb: take a pad or piano note, send it into a shimmer reverb with pitch +12 → it becomes an atmospheric carpet that moves.

  • Noise layers: ambient recordings (wind, road, rustling) filtered in tight band-pass → give that "dirty" feel that Massive Attack used in the backgrounds.

  • Reverse FX: reverbs or delays rendered, then reversed, put to fill in between hits. Super "cinematic trip-hop."

** Result:

  • Slow, warm, dark rhythm section → Massive Attack.

  • Endless spaces and breathing textures → Brian Eno.

  • Together = your signature dark/ambient/downtempo sound.

docs.title: Trip Hop  Ambient
docs.text: Trip-Hop / Ambient Style Voices

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Voices dark, enveloping, hypnotic, which do not dominate as in pop but become part of the atmosphere.

docs.title: 1. Basic EQ
docs.text:
• High Cut: 8-10 kHz (to take away pop brilliance).
  • Low Cut: 100 Hz (to clean up sub).
  • Soft boost at 300-500 Hz if heat is needed.

docs.title: 2. Compressor
docs.text:
• Circuit: Opto (Logic's Vintage Opto)
  • Ratio: 2-3:1
  • Attack: medium (30 ms)
  • Release: 150 ms
  • Gain Reduction: 3-5 dB -> Soft compression, without pumping, so the voice remains velvety.

docs.title: 3. Delay
docs.text:
• Stereo Delay:
    • L: 1/4, R: 1/8
    • Feedback: 15-20%
    • Mix: 20-25% -> Dark, rhythmic delay that "dances" behind the voice.
  • Optional: 4-5 kHz low pass on return → dark delay.

docs.title: 4. Reverb
docs.text:
• Medium plate (1.5-2s) dark → for presence.
  • Hall long (3-4s) filtered → for ambience.-> Often two reverbs in parallel: a short one to "glue" it, a long one to float it.

docs.title: 5. Creative effects
docs.text:
• Mild distortion (Overdrive Drive 2 dB, Tone 3-4 kHz) → gives grit.
  • Slow tremolo (Rate 1/2, Depth 15%) → hypnotic movement.
  • Reverse reverb on phrases → kinematic atmosphere.

docs.title: 6. Voice Bus.
docs.text:
• You can create a dedicated Aux: glue VCA compressor + soft saturation.
  • Generous sends to Ambient Reverbs and Textures → vocals blend with soundscape.

docs.title: Final Character
docs.text:
• Voice not "pop foreground," but atmospheric instrument inside the mix.
  • Dark, hypnotic, with rhythmic delays and layered reverbs.
  • Perfect mood for ambient, downtempo, trip-hop.

-> Even if your tracks remain instrumental, you could use this recipe for: - filtered AI vocal phrases, - spoken samples taken from field recordings, - or even hum/whisper as textures.

docs.title: Harmonial con Drum Machine Designer
docs.text: Harmonial Kit in Drum Machine Designer

docs.title: 1. Create Drum Machine Designer track
docs.text:
1. Go to Track → New instrument software track.
  2. Choose Drum Machine Designer as the instrument.
  3. A blank kit with 16 pads opens.

docs.title: 2. Load the samples
docs.text:
• Drags audio bounces (those exported from Harmonial) directly to DMD's pads.
  • Each pad hosts an instance of Quick Sampler automatically.
  • Now you already have the samples mapped to the pads!

docs.title: 3. Configure the pads
docs.text:
• Click on a pad → Quick Sampler opens.
  • Set Mode = One Shot (perfect for single shots).
  • If the sample is a loop, you can choose Slice or Classic for more control.
  • Adjust start/end points, pitch and filters for each sample.

docs.title: 4. Playing with pads
docs.text:
• If you have a MIDI controller with pads (like MPK Mini, Launchpad, Push, etc.), Logic will map the DMD pads automatically to your corresponding MIDI keys (usually C1 → first pad).
  • Otherwise you can play them from your regular MIDI keyboard: the samples are chromatically mapped from the C1 keys on up.

docs.title: 5. Save the kit.
docs.text:
• When you are satisfied, go to File → Save as Patch....
  • Give it a name (e.g. Harmonial DMD Kit 01).
  • You will now find it in the Drum Kits library.

-> Creative Tip: You can mix Harmonial bounces with traditional drum hits → e.g., regular kick and snare + Harmonial glitches on other pads. You will have a very original hybrid kit!

Do you want me to make you a chart-like graphic pad map (4x4) with an idea of how to arrange Harmonial samples (e.g., glitch on top, bass on the bottom, textures on the sides)?

docs.title: 1. Capture the moment
docs.text:
• Let Harmonial Binauris run until something comes out that inspires you.
  • Make Bounce in Place right away.
  • Don't overthink it: accumulate lots of audio "clips," even short ones. It's like sampling your own synth.

docs.title: 2. Chopping and re-arranging
docs.text:
• Cut bounces into chunks (even 1/4 or 1/8 of a beat).
  • Rearrange the fragments to create new patterns, kind of like with a sampler.
  • If you want, use Strip Silence in Logic to have it help you automatically separate notes.

docs.title: 3. Time-stretching & Flex
docs.text:
• Enable Flex Time (Polyphonic or Slicing).
  • Stretch or tighten the fragments to match the groove of the song.
  • You can also get very interesting glitch and stutter effects.

docs.title: 4. Layering
docs.text:
• Duplicate the same clip and transpose it ±12 semitones.
  • Pan wide L/R → get spatial textures.
  • Or duplicate and process differently (one with reverb, the other with distortion).

docs.title: 5. Granulation & glitches
docs.text:
• Load bounces into a granular plugin (e.g. Alchemy which is already inside Logic).
  • Turn patterns into atmospheric pads, alien sounds or cinematic drones.

docs.title: 6. Infinite resampling
docs.text:
• When you have created an interesting layer, do Bounce in Place again.
  • Then repeat: cut, transpose, stretch →new still different material.
  • It's like building an archive of original samples just your own.

-> Basically, Harmonial becomes your machine of surprises, and with audio bounces you turn it into a real personal sample library. Do you want me to make you a quick map with key Logic commands (like shortcuts for bounce, flex, strip silence, etc.), so you have the creative flow always at your fingertips?

docs.title: Harmonial in Sampler
docs.text: Workflow - From Bounce to Sampler

docs.title: 1. Prepare Samples
docs.text:
• Use Bounce in Place to generate your fragments from Harmonial.
  • Cut the samples into individual notes or loops (even micro-loops if you want "grainy" sounds).
  • Save them all in a dedicated folder (e.g. Harmonial Samples).

docs.title: 2. Create a new Sampler
docs.text:
1. Add a new software instrument track.
  2. In the Channel Strip load Sampler.
  3. The Sampler window opens.

docs.title: 3. Import samples
docs.text:
• Drag your audio files directly into the Sampler window.
  • Logic will ask you how to map:
    • Chromatic Mapping → puts each sample on a different, consecutive note.
    • Optimized Mapping → try to infer the original note (if there is pitch info in the file).
    • One Shot → useful if you want to trigger loops or single shots.

docs.title: 4. Editing in the Sampler
docs.text:
• Adjust Start/End to cut each sample well.
  • Set Loop if you want a sample to keep running.
  • Use the Envelopes (ADSR) to shape attack and release.
  • Play with Filter, Pitch and Modulation to transform the sound.

docs.title: 5. Save the instrument
docs.text:
• From the Sampler menu choose Save As... and give it a name (e.g., Harmonial Kit 01).
  • Now you can always find it in your Sampler library.

💡 Creative Tip: You can create a real atonal drum kit by putting Harmonial patterns or glitches on multiple keys, so you can "play" the fragments as if it were an MPC.

Kit 8 Samples in Logic Sampler

docs.title: 1. Set up the samples
docs.text:
• Bounce 8 different fragments (e.g., glitches, loops, single notes) from Harmonial.
  • Save them in a folder (e.g. Harmonial Kit 01).
  • Ideally name the files in order: Sample01.wav ... Sample08.wav.

docs.title: 2. Create the Sampler track
docs.text:
1. Add new software instrument track.
  2. Load Sampler as an instrument.

docs.title: 3. Import samples
docs.text:
1. Open the Sampler window.
  2. Drag in the 8 samples.
  3. In the mapping window, choose Zone per sample.
  4. Place each sample on a precise MIDI key (e.g. C1 to G1).

docs.title: 4. Map manually (if needed)
docs.text:
• Go to the Zone/Mapping view.
  • Assign each sample to a single note (range = 1 note).
    • Sample01 → C1
    • Sample02 → C#1
    • ...
    • Sample08 → G1

docs.title: 5. Optimize
docs.text:
• For each sample, set One Shot (so you hear the whole sample when you press the button).
  • If you want to loop, turn on Loop Mode.
  • Adjust ADSR: short attack, medium release to avoid clicks.

docs.title: 6. Save the Kit.
docs.text:
• From the Sampler menu → Save As... → Harmonial Kit 01.
  • Now you will find it in the Sampler library always ready.

-> Extra Tip: You can duplicate the Sampler track and load 8 more samples → so you create Harmonial Kit 02, 03..., each with different sounds to play live on the keyboard.

docs.title: 1. Track Generator

docs.title: 2. Audio Recorder Track

docs.title: 3. Manipulation Track
docs.text:
• Type: Audio

  • Enable Flex (Polyphonic or Slicing, depends on what kind of editing you want to do).
  • Rename: Audio FX / Flex

docs.title: 4. Creative Effects (Bus FX)
docs.text: Set 2-3 Aux to process quickly: - Bus 10 → Reverb (e.g. Chromaverb). - Bus 11 → Delay (Stereo Delay or Tape Delay). - Bus 12 → Crusher/Distortion All preconfigured sends (send) on the track Audio FX / Flex.

docs.title: 5. Workflow ready
docs.text:
1. Arm Audio Capture and press R → record on the fly what comes out of Harmonial.
  2. Immediately drag the recorded file to the Audio FX / Flex track.
  3. Apply Flex, chopping, strip silence, etc.
  4. If you create something beautiful → Ctrl+B (Bounce in Place) and accumulate new clips ready to be reused.

docs.title: 6. Save Template
docs.text:
• Go to File → Save as Template...
  • Call it: Harmonial Resampler
  • So you find it every time in the "New Project from Template" menu.

-> With this setup you basically use Harmonial as a random generator of unique samples, and in two clicks you are already ready to record, manipulate and layer without wasting time with tedious routing.

docs.title: Complete Workflow with Harmonial Binaurics in Logic Pro.
docs.text: Workflow guide for getting the most out of Harmonial Binaurics in Logic Pro, including multi-out configurations, resampling, and transformation into playable instruments.

docs.title: 1. Multi-Out Configuration
docs.text:
1. Create a software instrument track.
  2. Load Harmonial Binaurics (Multi Output, 8 Stereo).
  3. In the Mixer View, click the + symbol next to the plugin channel.
  4. Logic adds 7 aux channels, each with independent insert, send, and routing.
  5. All audio from Harmonial comes out of Out 1-2, but the aux channels can be used for creative routing.

docs.title: 2.1 Parallel Processing
docs.text:
• Out 1-2 → Clean (dry) sound
  • Aux 1 → Dedicated reverb
  • Aux 2 → Dedicated delay
  • Aux 3 → Distortion/Crusher
  • Aux 4 → Modulation effects

docs.title: 2.2 Frequency Separation.
docs.text: Using EQ or a multiband splitter: - Out 1-2 → Bass (0-120 Hz) - Aux 1 → Mid-bass (120-500 Hz) - Aux 2 → Medium-high (500-5 kHz) - Aux 3 → Treble (5 kHz+)

docs.title: 2.3 Multichannel Resampling
docs.text:
• Out 1-2 → Main source
  • Aux 1 → Parallel audio track
  • Aux 2 → Bus with granular FX
  • Aux 3 → Bus with infinite reverb

docs.title: 2.4 Live Performance
docs.text:
• Out 1-2 → Main sound
  • Aux 1 → FX Chain A (reverb + delay)
  • Aux 2 → FX Chain B (distortion + compression)
  • Aux 3 → FX Chain C (phaser + chorus)

docs.title: 3. Multichannel Resampling
docs.text:
1. Routes aux outputs to audio tracks.
  2. Arms all audio tracks and records in real time.
  3. Capture parallel recordings with different versions of the signal.
  4. Saves audio fragments in dedicated folders for sample organization.

docs.title: 4. Building Kits with Sampler
docs.text:
1. Add a software instrument track.
  2. Load Sampler.
  3. Drag the recorded samples to the mapping window.
  4. Recommended mapping:
  5. Chromatic Mapping → one sample per consecutive key
  6. One Shot → for glitches and single shots
  7. Adjust ADSR, filters, pitch.
  8. Save as patch (e.g. Harmonial_Sampler_Kit01).

docs.title: 5. Building Kits with Drum Machine Designer (DMD)
docs.text:
1. Add a software instrument track.
  2. Load Drum Machine Designer.
  3. Drag the samples onto the pads.
  4. Each pad opens Quick Sampler with independent controls.
  5. Organize the pads by category:
  6. Bottom row → drone and bass
  7. Middle row → rhythm loops
  8. Top row → glitches and textures
  9. Save as a patch (e.g. Harmonial_DMD_Kit01).

docs.title: 6.1 Chopping
docs.text:
• Cut into short fragments (1/16, 1/8).
  • Rearrange to create new patterns.
  • Use Strip Silence for automatic separation.

docs.title: 6.2 Granular
docs.text:
• Import into Alchemy in Granular mode.
  • Experiment with density and modulation.

docs.title: 6.3 Layering
docs.text:
• Duplicate a sample, transpose ±12 semitones.
  • Pan left/right.
  • Apply different FX to each layer.

docs.title: 6.4 Stretching
docs.text:
• Use Flex Time.
  • Stretch/compress to adapt to time or create glitches.

docs.title: 6.5 Reverse
docs.text:
• Creates inverted versions of samples.
  • Crossfade between original and reverse.

docs.title: 6.6 Iterative Resampling.
docs.text:
1. Generates material from Harmonial.
  2. Bounce in Place and slice.
  3. Load samples into Sampler/DMD.
  4. Play new patterns and record.
  5. Repeat the cycle to build increasingly complex libraries.

docs.title: 7. Practical Tips
docs.text:
• Use color coding on aux channels to distinguish functions.
  • Save the setup as a Template or Patch to speed up the workflow.
  • Think of Harmonial as a raw source to be sculpted by routing and parallel processing.

docs.title: SD3   Come separare le uscite di Superior Drummer in Logic Pro
How to separate the outputs of Superior Drummer in Logic Pro.
1. Load Superior as a Multi-Output instrument.
docs.text:
• Go to Track → New Software Instrument Track.

  • In the window that opens, under Track Type, choose: "Instrument" → "AU Instruments → Toontrack → Superior Drummer → Multi Output (16xStereo) " (or 8xStereo if you don't need too many outputs).

  • Click Create.

docs.title: 2. Activate the outputs in Logic.
docs.text:
• Go to the Mixer in Logic (X key).

  • Find the Superior Drummer track.

  • At the bottom, on the plugin channel, you will see a little "+" (next to the instrument name).

  • Click the "+" as many times as the outputs you need (kick, snare, hat, toms, overheads, room...).

  • Logic will automatically create corresponding aux channels.

docs.title: 3. Assigns the outputs inside Superior
docs.text:
• Open Superior Drummer and go into the Internal Mixer of the plugin.

  • For each channel (Kick, Snare Top, Snare Bottom, HH, Toms, OH, Room, etc.) choose a different output:

    • Kick → Output 1 (stereo or mono depending on configuration)

    • Snare Top → Output 2

    • Snare Bottom → Output 3

    • Hi-Hat → Output 4

    • ... and so on.

  • Now Logic will receive the separate signals in the aux channels created in step 2.

docs.title: 4. Mix in Logic
docs.text:
• Each aux is now an independent audio track:

    • You can insert EQ, compression, reverb, delay, etc.

    • you can adjust volumes separately, do automations, etc.

-> The MIDI always remains on one track, but at the audio level you have the drums completely split.

docs.title: Where the split outputs appear in Logic.
docs.text:
1. Go to the Mixer in Logic (X on the keyboard).

  2. Find the Superior Drummer track. It is the Instrument Channel Strip (the one with the plugin loaded).

  3. At the bottom of the channel, you will see a small "+"button next to the fader.

    • This button is used to create the Aux Channels corresponding to the additional outputs.

    • Click "+" as many times as there are outputs you have assigned in Superior's internal mixer (kick, snare, hi-hat, etc.).

  4. As soon as you click, Logic adds new Aux Channels to the right of the main track.

    • E.g. Aux 1 = Snare, Aux 2 = Hi-Hat, Aux 3 = Toms, Aux 4 = Overheads... (depends on how you mapped them inside Superior).

    • These channels have their own fader, insert, send, pan, like any audio track.

-> Superior's original track still remains the "mother track": it houses the MIDI and usually picks up the Kick (Output 1). All other parts instead come on the auxes.

docs.title: Typical example in Mixer.
docs.text:
After activating the outputs, in Logic's Mixer you might see something like this:

  • Inst 1 - Superior Drummer (Instrument Channel) → Kick

  • Aux 1 → Snare Top

  • Aux 2 → Snare Bottom

  • Aux 3 → Hi-Hat

  • Aux 4 → Toms

  • Aux 5 → Overheads

  • Aux 6 → Room

And so on.

docs.title: Recommended Routing (Multi-Output in Superior Drummer).
docs.text:
Inside Superior's Mixer assigns like this:

  • Output 1-2 (Main Stereo / Logic's Inst Channel) → Kick

  • Output 3-4 → Snare (Top + Bottom, or keep Top alone if you want more control)

  • Output 5-6 → Hi-Hat

  • Outputs 7-8 → Toms (you can group them together or make individual outputs if you want a super detailed mix)

  • Outputs 9-10 → Overheads (OH)

  • Outputs 11-12 → Room (Environments)

  • Outputs 13-14 → Extra percussions (shakers, claps, etc., if any)

docs.title: How it translates into Logic
docs.text:
When you click the "+" in the Superior track (in Logic's Mixer), you will get:

  • Inst 1 (Superior Drummer - Kick)

  • Aux 1 (Snare)

  • Aux 2 (Hi-Hat)

  • Aux 3 (Toms)

  • Aux 4 (Overheads)

  • Aux 5 (Room)

  • Aux 6 (Extra Percussion)

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Separate Kick and Snare: you can EQ them and compress them as you like.

  • Hi-Hat on its own channel: useful for handling reverb and treble.

  • Separate Overheads and Room: total control of "air" and spaciousness.

  • Toms: you can keep them together or split them into multiple outputs if you want to treat each tom individually.

-> I recommend saving this setup as preset of Superior's mixer, so every time you open the plugin you already have the routing ready.

docs.title: How to better orient yourself
docs.text:
1. Rename the Aux channels in Logic (e.g. "Snare", "Hi-Hat", "Toms"...) so you don't get confused with numbers.

    • Just click on the channel name below the fader and type in the name.

  2. In Superior Drummer, match the outputs:

    • Snare → Out 3/4

    • Hi-Hat → Out 5/6

    • etc.

  3. Then in Logic, the first aux you created (even though it's called Aux 18) will correspond to Out 3/4, the second to Out 5/6, etc.

-> Basically: don't worry about the number (18, 19, 20...), they're just labels. The important thing is that each audio output of Superior has its own dedicated Aux.

docs.title: What to check in Superior Drummer.
docs.text:
1. Open Superior Drummer and go into the Internal Mixer of the plugin.

  2. Look at the channel strips (Kick, Snare Top, Snare Bottom, Hi-Hat, etc.).

  3. At the bottom of each channel strip is a drop-down menu that says the output (usually by default it is "Out 1/2").

  4. Change the Snare (or what you want to separate) from Out 1/2 → Out 3/4.

  5. Now on Logic, Aux 18 will receive the signal.

docs.title: Quick check
docs.text:
• Play the MIDI track (or tap a Snare pad in Superior).

  • You should see the meter move to Aux 18.

  • Now you can enter plugins, EQ, compression, automations, etc.

-> Summarizing: routing must be done twice

  • in Superior Drummer → assign each piece of kit to a different output.

docs.title: - in Logic → create the corresponding auxes with the "+".
How cymbals work in Superior
docs.text:
• Cymbals are recorded in the Overheads (OH) and Room/Ambience microphones.

  • You will almost never find them as a separate "Crash 1" or "Ride" channel, because in a real studio, cymbals are not miked individually (except in special cases).

  • So:

    • if you move the OH to an output, you'll hear all the cymbals in there.

    • the Rooms/Environments always contain the dishes as well (in addition to all the kit).

docs.title: What you can do if you want more control
docs.text:
1. Adjust the balance in Superior's mixer.

    • Inside Superior you can often lower the "Bleed" (the amount of cymbals going into the Room, Snare, etc. mics).

    • You can also manage how much each individual cymbal goes into the OHs.

  2. Separate Ride or Crash (when possible)

    • In some Superior libraries there are spot mics dedicated at least to Ride (important cymbal in the mix).

    • If your library provides them, you can send them on a separate output.

  3. Alternative trick

    • If you need even more surgical control (like different compression for Ride and Crash), you can duplicate the MIDI:

      • On one track you keep only the Ride,

      • on another just the Crash,

      • and you load two instances of Superior with different routings.

    • It is a little more CPU heavy, but gives you more freedom.

-> Basically: dishes "live" on the Overheads and Room, not as individual channels.

docs.title: Typical routing (multi-out in Superior Drummer → Logic Pro).
docs.text:
• Kick → Out 1/2 (stays on the main channel of Superior)

  • Snare (Top + Bottom) → Out 3/4

  • Hi-Hat → Out 5/6

  • Toms (all together, or separate if you want more control) → Out 7/8

  • Overheads (all cymbals) → Out 9/10

  • Room/Ambience → Out 11/12

-> This is the "basic package" you need to mix well.

docs.title: Because it works like this
docs.text:
• Kick and Snare: individually mic'd → it pays to treat them with dedicated EQ and compression.

  • Hi-Hat: dedicated spot mic, useful for adjusting reverb and controlling treble.

  • Toms: you can keep them together (Out 7/8) or split them (Tom 1 → 7/8, Tom 2 → 9/10, etc.) if you want more surgical mix.

  • Overheads: here you hear the whole kit, but especially the cymbals. You can control brightness and stereo.

  • Room: adds depth and realistic "air" → you can compress hard for more punch.

docs.title: Practical tip
docs.text:
Once this routing is set up:

  1. Rename the auxes to Logic (Kick, Snare, HH, Toms, OH, Room).

  2. Save everything as a preset in Superior Drummer and also as a patch in Logic → so when you open a new project you are ready without redoing the setup.

docs.title: How to save routing as a preset in Superior Drummer.
docs.text:
1. Open the Internal Mixer of Superior Drummer.

  2. Assign the outputs as I told you (typical example):

    • Kick → Out 1/2

    • Snare (Top+Bottom) → Out 3/4

    • Hi-Hat → Out 5/6

    • Toms → Out 7/8

    • Overheads → Out 9/10

    • Room → Out 11/12

  3. Once everything sounds and the meters in Logic move correctly:

    • Go to the top right of the Superior Drummer window.

    • Open the Presets menu.

    • Choose Save Mixer Preset (in SD3 it is called that).

    • Give it a name like: Logic MultiOut Routing.

docs.title: How to call it back after
docs.text:
• Whenever you open a new instance of Superior Drummer:

    1. Load the kit you want.

    2. Go to the Presets menu → Load Mixer Preset.

    3. Select Logic MultiOut Routing.

  • Boom!!! You already have all the outputs assigned, without redoing anything.

-> Extra Tip: You can also save directly in Logic a Channel Strip Setting or even a Project Template with Superior already in Multi-Output mode and the Auxes renamed. That way you always start with the setup ready.

docs.title: Where to save the routing (SD3).
docs.text:
1. Go to the Internal Mixer in Superior Drummer.

  2. At the top left of the Mixer you will see a small drop-down menu (icon with an arrow).

    • There you will find options like:

      • Reset Mixer

      • Save Mixer Preset

      • Load Mixer Preset

  3. Choose Save Mixer Preset.

    • You will be asked for a name → write, for example, Logic MultiOut.

docs.title: Then to reload it
docs.text:
• When you open a new project and load SD3:

    • Go back to the Mixer → same menu → Load Mixer Preset → choose Logic MultiOut.

  • The routing assignments to the outputs (Out 1/2, Out 3/4, etc.) return immediately as you had saved them.

-> Note: If you don't see it right away, make sure you are in the Mixer tab of SD3 (not in Drums, Grooves, etc.). The menu is right above the channel strips.

docs.title: 1. Channel Strip Setting (the one you find at the top of the Logic strip).
docs.text:
• If you save only the main instrument (the "Superior Drummer" track), Logic remembers the plugin, its presets and internal routings on that track only.

  • It doesn't also automatically recall your linked auxes (the ones created with the "+"), though. Those have to be recreated every time. -> So: not enough if you want to call up the whole multi-output setup already expanded.

docs.title: 2. Track Stack (Summing Stack) + saving as Patch.
docs.text:
• If you put Superior's track + all Aux inside a Summing Stack:

    1. select the track of SD3 + all its Aux.

    2. Menu Track → Create Track Stack → choose Summing Stack.

    3. Rename the stack, such as Superior MultiOut.

  • Now go to the Browser on the left (Inspector → Patch Library) and click on Save....

  • This saves a complete Patch, with in it:

    • the tool (SD3),

    • the Auxes already created and connected,

    • all plugins on the auxes,

    • names and routing.

-> When you call it up in a new project, it recreates the whole group: instrument + Aux + routing mixer.

docs.title: 3. Project template (the "ultimate" method).
docs.text:
• If you always use that setup, the most convenient is to do:

    1. Open an empty project, put SD3 in Multi-Output, create the Auxes, put everything in Track Stack.

    2. Go to File → Save as Template.

    3. When you open Logic, it will show up in your initial templates → click and you're up and running.

-> Summarizing:

  • Channel Strip Setting = saves only the main track (not the Aux).

  • Track Stack saved as Patch = recall everything, including Aux and routing.

  • Project Template = even better if you always want to have that setup ready to go.

docs.title: Save your Track Stack as a Patch.
docs.text:
1. Select the Track Stack (the Summing Stack with SD3 and all the Auxes in it).

  2. With the Library open (left), you see a Save... button at the top.

  3. Click Save → give it a name (e.g. Superior MultiOut).

  4. Now your patch appears under User Patches.

-> When in a new project you open the Library (Y key) you can recall it in one click: it recreates your whole SD3 + Aux + routing group.

docs.title: Recall the Superior Drummer Multi-Out Patch.
docs.text:
1. Create a new software instrument track (even empty).

    • It can be an empty MIDI track, it doesn't matter.

  2. With that track selected, press Y to open the Library (left column).

  3. Go to User Patches → you will find your saved patch (Superior MultiOut or whatever you called it).

  4. Click on it → Logic loads automatically:

    • Superior Drummer in Multi-Output mode

    • All Aux already ready and renamed

    • Routing the same as you had saved it

  5. Now just drag in the MIDI region of the drum kit (or record directly) and you're up and running.

-> Little tip: If you often open projects where you need that patch right away, consider making a Project Template with the track already in it → that way you don't even have to go through the Library.

docs.title: Here are some veteran tricks that may come in handy with Superior Drummer + Logic Pro:
1. Rename the aux right away.
docs.text: As soon as you create the Auxes (Kick, Snare, OH, Room...), rename them in the Mixer (⌘ + click on the name) → so even in automations and effects you always know what you are dealing with.

docs.title: 2. Color the tracks.
docs.text: Assign different colors (e.g., red = kick/snare, blue = cymbals, green = toms, purple = ambience). It helps so much at a glance when you have so many tracks.

docs.title: 3. Folder Track for cleaning.
docs.text: If you don't want to use a Stack, you can put all the Aux inside a Folder Track → so you close/open the folder and they don't clog up your project.

docs.title: 4. fast stem bounces.
docs.text: When you're satisfied with the routing, you can Bounce in Place each Aux → you get your audio tracks already printed (useful for archiving light projects or sending tracks to an outside sound engineer).

docs.title: 5. Use Internal Buses
docs.text:
• Create a Bus Drums and send all the Aux there.

  • On that bus put parallel compression, saturation or a global reverb. -> So you have both control over the individual pieces and a "glue" on the kit.

docs.title: 6. Save multiple versions
docs.text:
You can make multiple different patches:

  • a "clean" one with only routing,

  • one with already basic EQ and compressors,

  • one more "ambient/dark" with reverb ready. In one click you take your whole style with you.

💡 Bonus: If you often use the same kit as SD3, save it directly as User Preset inside Superior → so you recall both sounds and routing without touching anything in Logic.

docs.title: Your SD3 / EZX libraries - Analysis for Ambient / Trip-Hop use.
Very useful for trip-hop / dark ambient
docs.text:
• SL-HansaRooms → huge rooms, super cinematic recordings → gold for Eno/Massive Attack atmospheres.

  • EZX2_DreamPop → soft kick, velvety snare, dense environments → perfect for downtempo, ambient.

  • EZX2_HipHop → immediately trip-hop, dark heavy kick drum, dry snare → great layering with acoustic kits.

  • EZX_Electronic → electronic samples useful for hybrid layers (like Recipe layering Massive Attack).

  • EZX2_Post-Rock → great for big reverbs and dark textures, more "cinematic".

docs.title: Useful as variation/color
docs.text:
• SL-FieldsOfRock → powerful kits, great if you want more aggressive, rocking drums → you can darken them for harder Massive Attack style stuff.

  • EZX_Percussion → perfect for enriching with hypnotic percussion and slow grooves (shakers, dark bongos, congas).

  • EZX_Jazz → useful for dark brushes and rides → more acoustic/organic sound.

  • EZX2_Reggae → dry hi-hats, rimshots, dub sounds → very suitable for trip-hop/dub ambient moods.

  • EZX2_Southern70s → vintage kits, dark, great for downtempo grooves.

docs.title: More "off target," but creatively usable
docs.text:
• SL-Hitmaker / HitmakerElec → much more modern pop/EDM → but you can filter and dirty the samples to get interesting contrasts.

  • EZX2_PopRock / Southern60s / Americana / dfh / Funkmaster Clyde & Jabo → more rock, pop or funk oriented → not the core for trip-hop, but if you filter and process them (bitcrusher, tape, dark EQ) they can become useful textures or layers.

docs.title: Practical tip
docs.text: For your ambient/downtempo/trip-hop style, I would mainly focus on: -> Hansa Rooms + DreamPop + HipHop + Post-Rock + Electronic. And I would use: -> Percussion + Reggae + Jazz as extras for color and hypnotic grooves.

  2. Prefix S2D01_ in front → your presets always stay at the top of the list.

Perfect!!! So you have SD3 and Logic synchronized in the same mental order → less chaos, more speed.

docs.title: 1. Build the kit.
docs.text:
• Choose the instruments (kick/snare/room/perc) from the libraries.

  • Set levels and routing in SD3's internal mixer (assign multiple outputs if needed).

  • Apply minimal EQ/Comp already if you want, or leave it clean and process in Logic.

docs.title: 2. Save as Mixer Preset.
docs.text:
• Go to the Mixer in SD3.

  • Top right menu → Save Mixer Preset As....

  • Example name:

    • S2D01 Massive Attack Kit.

    • S2D01 Ambient Eno Kit -> So you save routing, levels, any internal effects.

docs.title: 3. (Optional) Also save as User Preset Kit.
docs.text:
• Go to the SD3 main menu (loaded instruments).

  • Save As... → User Preset. -> This saves not only the mixer but also the choice of drums themselves.

docs.title: 4. Use the Song Track
docs.text:
• In the Song Track you can put a MIDI groove (even a trivial one).

  • Associate a kit → so you have a preview of the sound right away.

  • You can also save here as a Song Track Preset (so you recall kit + groove).

docs.title: Practical workflow for you
docs.text:
• If you only want sounds → save as Mixer Preset and User Preset Kit.

  • If you want a ready to "play" kit with a groove → save as Song Track Preset.

-> This way in 2 clicks you can switch between:

  • S2D01 Massive Attack Kit.

  • S2D01 Ambient Eno Kit

...without rebuilding anything from scratch

docs.title: Ambient Kit / Brian Eno with your SD3/EZX libraries.
1. Kick (subtle pulse)
docs.text:
• Use a soft kick from DreamPop or Post-Rock → no attack, just body.

  • EQ: low pass at 150 Hz → only the "pulse" remains. -> Must sound more like a "breath" than a drum beat.

docs.title: 2. Snare / Rim / Texture
docs.text:
• Get a dry rimshot from EZX2_Reggae or a small snare from DreamPop**.

  • EQ: filter everything above 6-7 kHz → darkest.

  • Process with long reverb (4-6s, filtered) and dark ping-pong delay. -> Becomes an "atmospheric event," not a groove snare.

docs.title: 3. Hi-Hats & Cymbals
docs.text:
• Use very soft HH from Jazz or DreamPop.

  • High Cut: 6-7 kHz → no shine.

  • Optional: insert a very short stereo delay (10-15 ms) → wide whisper effect. -> They must sound like ambient rustles.

docs.title: 4. Creative percussions
docs.text:
• EZX Percussion: get shakers, drums, small hand percussion.

  • Apply slow tremolo (1/2, Depth 30%) → hypnotic pulse.

  • Send in Textures Bus shimmer -12 semitones → become "sub-aquatic" sounds.

docs.title: 5. Room & Ambience
docs.text:
• HansaRooms → use large rooms, long decay.

  • Compressed slightly (VCA 2:1, GR 1-2 dB).

  • High Cut 5 kHz to darken. -> Here Room is more important than the drums themselves.

docs.title: 6. Bus Drums Ambient
docs.text:
• EQ: cuts below 80 Hz (leaves the synthetic bass the space).

  • Comp Opto soft (2:1 ratio, GR 2 dB).

  • Massive send to your Reverbs Ambient and Textures Extra-Dark buses.

docs.title: Final Character
docs.text:
• Barely perceptible kick → pulse rather than rhythm.

  • Snare/perc. transformed into spatial events.

  • Hi-hat become filtered swooshes.

  • Giant, dark, enveloping room.

    -> Result = atmospheric instrument more than "drums," perfect for ambient/drone/ethereal downtempo.

docs.title: 1. Kick (fundamental)
docs.text:
• Basic: EZX2_HipHop → choose a dark, round, no-click kick.

  • Layer: DreamPop kick → adds soft body.

  • Processing in Logic:

    • EQ: boost at 60 Hz (+3 dB), cut at 250 Hz (-2/3 dB).

    • Slow comp (attack 30 ms, release 100 ms).

    • If you want electronic beat → add a sub-kick from the EZX_Electronic, filtered LPF 100 Hz.

docs.title: 2. Snare
docs.text:
• Base: DreamPop snare → velvety, dark.

  • Layer: dry clap/snare from the EZX2_HipHop → only on the highs (HPF 800 Hz).

  • Optional: a rimshot from EZX2_Reggae for "dub" color.

  • Processing in Logic:

    • EQ: low cut 120 Hz, boost 200 Hz (+2 dB), presence +3 dB at 2.5-3 kHz.

    • Light saturation (Overdrive Drive 2 dB).

    • Room: sends snare into the Room of HansaRooms → loud compression (trip-hop style pump).

docs.title: 3. Hi-Hat & Cymbals
docs.text:
• Get HH from DreamPop or HipHop → turn down volume, high cut 8-9 kHz.

  • Overheads → almost nothing.

  • Processing: short ping-pong delay (1/16), low feedback.

docs.title: 4. Room & Ambience
docs.text:
• Use HansaRooms → one of the large rooms.

  • Raise the Room more than the norm (it becomes part of the sound).

  • Compressor FET 1176, ratio 8:1, fast attack, medium release → pump.

  • High Cut 6 kHz to keep it dark.

docs.title: 5. Extra percussions
docs.text:
• Add from EZX Percussion (dark shaker, filtered drum).

  • Treat them with slow tremolo or tape delay → hypnotic groove.

docs.title: 6. Bus Drums Processing
docs.text:
• Glue Comp (VCA, ratio 2:1, attack 30 ms, release 100 ms, GR 2-3 dB).

  • Parallel Punch (see your Saturn/1176 chain).

  • Send to your Reverbs Ambient and Textures Shimmer buses to put them in the space.

docs.title: Final Character
docs.text:
• Deep, dark kick with electronic sub underneath.

  • Velvety snare + dry clap → hypnotic groove.

  • Hi-hat filtered, almost hidden.

  • Compressed room that "breathes."

  • Minimal percussion pulsing.

    -> Result = Massive Attack style without buying more libraries.

docs.title: Key Commands - S2D01 Workflow
docs.text:
You can assign custom Key Commands (Logic → Key Commands → Edit):

  • "Create New Aux Channel Strip" → put a key of your choice (like F5).

  • "Bypass All Plug-ins on Selected Channel Strips" → put F6.

-> Like this:

  • press F5 → Aux again ready to load an FX.

  • press F6 → Aux selected mutated in one shot (Light mode).

docs.title: FX Bus Management
docs.text:
• F5 → Create New Aux Channel Strip. (add an FX bus now, to go from Light to Full)

  • F6 → Bypass All Plug-ins on Selected Channel Strips. (take your FX buses offline = Light mode)

  • F7 → Delete Selected Channel Strips. (if you want to clean the mixer from the unused Auxes)

docs.title: Send Management
docs.text:
• ⌥Click on Send knob → reset to -∞

  • Shift+⌥Drag → copy the same send level to multiple tracks. -> Use it to send the whole Drum Stack together to an FX bus.

docs.title: Mix / Bus Control
docs.text:
• Ctrl+⌘+↑ / ↓ → Quickly switch between Input/Bus/Output in the Mixer.

  • F8 → Toggle Bypass Sends (you can assign it). (turns you off/on all sends of a track → Instant Light/Full).

docs.title: How to configure them
docs.text:
1. Go to Logic Pro → Key Commands → Edit...
  2. Search for the command (e.g. Create New Aux Channel Strip).
  3. Press the key you want to assign (F5, F6, etc.).
  4. Save as S2D01.keycommands → so you always have your profile ready.

-> Result:

  • Press F5 → New Aux (Reverb, Texture, etc.).

  • Press F6 → Aux selected in Light mode (FX bypass).

  • Press F7 → Aux deleted.

  • Press F8 → Send instant ON/OFF.
